awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Collaborative Research: Aging In Place Through Enhanced Mobility and Social Connectedness: An Integrated Robot and Wearable Sensor Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The concept of "aging in place", using advanced technology to improve the health and well-being of older adults at home, has become popular as away to reduce costs and allow older adults the dignity of living their final years in the community. This project will use an integrated autonomous system that consists of a mobile robot and smart insole sensors to assist older adults to independently live in their own homes and interact with their communities.  The system will have two initial goals: supporting exercise and enhancing social connections. The target exercise is walking, the most preferred and accessible exercise modality among older adults. Regular walking exercises may result in enhanced balance, increased muscle strength, and reduced risk of falling.  The system guides individuals in regular walking exercises, autonomously assesses gait states, and provides real-time personalized feedback to engage older adults into the exercise. The robot will also be used to connect older adults with family and friends through a virtual connection. The project team will evaluate the system at a senior center in New York City using objective and subjective performance criteria measuring older adults' experiences with the system. This project serves the national interest because the integrated social assistive robot and wearable sensor system enhances mobility and social connectedness of older adults thus should improve their health and well-being. The project will involve an educational component that provides engineering and research method training to graduate and undergraduate students, as well as STEM outreach to middle and high-school students. Additional efforts will be made to attract and retain women and underrepresented minorities into careers in science and engineering.

This research investigates human-robot-sensor interaction, and aims to enhance mobility and social connectedness of older adults through the use of an assistive service robot. Methods to be developed include autonomous gait analysis combining sensing capability of robot onboard image sensors and the smart insoles through parametric and learning-based calibration models. The use of inverse reinforcement learning to explore cost function representation for robot motion planning. The use of dynamic recurrent neural networks and vibrotactile rhythmic stimuli for collaborative human-robot walking tasks. The project also examines the use of autonomous task scheduling to increase social contacts through telepresence robotic techniques. Finally, the implementation and experimental testing of the integrated system will be conducted in a senior center using objective and subjective performance criteria. The project fills a gap in aging-in-place research by providing an integrated robot and wearable sensor solution for enhancement of mobility and social connectedness. The developed methods will be implemented on open-source platforms, and the experimental and evaluation data will be made available for public use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The population of older adults is rapidly increasing. Aging populations have a greater need for health and disability support that places increased pressure on aged care and health services. This project proposes an integrated robot and wearable sensor system that guides older individuals in personalized walking exercises and provides online gait assessment. The project exploits human-robot-sensor interaction, and aims to enhance mobility and social connectedness of older adults through the use of an assistive service robot.

We have developed an autonomous gait analysis system consisting of a mobile robot and custom engineered instrumented insoles. The robot is equipped with an on-board Red Green Blue plus Depth (RGB-D) sensor, in addition to standard localization sensors. The insoles feature sensors including inertial measurement unit (IMU) and force sensitive resistors (FSRs). The robot guides a human user along a desired walking path and measures his/her gait patterns. We have assembled prototypes of the integrated system, and tested them in both laboratory environments and a senior center to engage older adults in walking exercises. Data fusion models were developed to extract accurate estimates of gait parameters from raw sensor data collected by the integrated system. Results suggested that the combined use of wearable and robot’s sensors yields more accurate gait estimates than either sub-system used independently.

To assess balance control and fall risk, it is desirable to continuously monitor dynamic stability during walking tasks. Dynamic Margin of Stability (MoS) is widely recognized as a quantitative measure for human walking stability and gait balance strategies. While camera-based motion capture systems (e.g., Vicon) are considered the gold-standard in determining the MoS, this equipment is expensive and can only be used in laboratory settings. To allow for continuous monitoring of MoS during users' daily living, and to overcome the limitations of wearable devices, we propose to use our developed integrated system to monitor and assess gait stability. We conducted experiments where the mobile robot leads human subjects in overground walking and collects data for gait and dynamic balance sensing. Utilizing both data from the Kinect sensor on the mobile robot and insole-embedded pressure and inertial sensors, we developed an online method for the robot to estimate MoS.  The results are compared with those obtained using a Vicon reference system in terms of Root-Mean-Square Error, and statistical analysis of human subjects show acceptable accuracy of MoS estimation.

Our developed integrated robot and wearable sensor system has been tested at the Sunnyside Community Services in Queens, NY, where over thirty participants between the ages of 65-85 were recruited. Participants came to the community center and completed a walking exercise with the insoles and our assistive robot. Before participating, the procedures were explained and participants provided written informed consent. After engaging in the walking exercise, participants completed a pencil and paper survey about their perceptions of aging, loneliness, and technology. Survey results indicate that greater comfort and love of technology and lower perceived loneliness were associated with more positive self-perceptions of aging. Participants also reported that the insoles were comfortable and did not hinder their ability to walk, and would generally welcome a robot at home or a robot to help them exercise. These results validated the feasibility of using such a portable system in out-of-the-lab conditions and will be helpful for designing future technology-enhanced exercise interventions to improve balance, mobility, and strength and potentially reduce falls in older adults.

The Sunnyside study also provided new insights into the associations between cognitive ability (measured by Montreal Cognitive Assessment scores) and gait and balance disturbances (spatiotemporal gait parameters and dynamic MoS) in older adults. Using our integrated mobile robot and wearable sensor system within a dual-task walking paradigm, we found evidence that a decline in cognitive ability among older adults is independently associated with more conservative overground gait patterns (i.e., smaller absolute values of the anteroposterior margin of stability) and increased gait variability (i.e., larger coefficients of variation in stride time and stride velocity). These findings offer proof-of-concept validation for the applicability of integrated robotic and wearable sensor technologies in out-of-lab gait analysis for older adults.

The project integrates research projects with education activities through enrichment of undergraduate and graduate education and training, and outreach to K-12 education. Students were trained in robotics, sensor fabrication/integration, real-time programming of embedded controllers, and data processing of human motion data. The research results have also enriched the curricula in the School of Engineering and School of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences at Stevens. Research results have been published in referred journals and international conferences and disseminated to the community.
